content.rendered:
10) The Independent Group for Change

It just wasn’t meant to be.

9) UKIP

Remember them?

8) Bolsover

David Skinner did lose his seat but ultimately Bolsover has lost their beast, and are worse off because of it.

7) Greens

Over 800,000 votes for just one seat and who says our electoral system isn’t broken?

6) DUP/ Nigel Dodds

In the preceding year the DUP have had more political power than they have ever enjoyed in their lifetime and what have they got to show for it? Their Westminster leader is out, there will be a border between Northern Ireland and the UK and  for the first time there are more nationalist than loyalist MPs in Northern Ireland. Nice.

5) Brexit Party

As entertaining as it would have been to see the polo-player and property millionaire Richard Tice represent the northern constituency of Hartlepool the Brexit Party couldn’t even manage that.

4) Independent Tories

Goodbye Dominic Grieve, Goodbye David Gauke, Goodbye uhhh everyone else. I don’t remember there being so many of them.

3) Heidi Allen / Unite for Remain

Two reasons why the Remain effort would be better off without Heidi Allen and the electoral pact between the Lib Dems, Greens and Plaid Cymru: Stroud and Kensington. Both constituencies could have potentially been won by Labour MPs if it wasn’t for Unite to Remain splitting the vote.

There are no reasons why the Remain effort would be better off with Heidi Allen as her pact failed to win any seats at all.

2) Jeremy Corbyn / Labour

He won the argument but he couldn’t convert it into a majority, which is why he will be top of my next list: 10 biggest winners in things that don’t matter this election.

1)Jo Swinson / Lib Dems

She called the election. She claimed she was essential to stopping Brexit and that she could be the next prime minister. Ultimately, she somehow ended up doing the polar opposite of both of these: unemployed and essential to getting Brexit done.

excerpt.rendered: The Monocle takes a look at this election.
